facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 1424 and 1612 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 1424 1612 of 1973. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights. V. Gupte

facts.text: Judgment delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J. The question for decision in these cases is about the liability

facts.text: Question concerns liability to sales tax under Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act on watery coconuts.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in these cases is about the liability to sales tax under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act of Watery companyonuts.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act contains four schedules.

anchor.surface_text: The Act companytains four schedules. The First Schedule companytains goods in respect of which a single point sales tax only is leviable under section 5 2   a .

facts.text: By amendment in 1961, coconuts in Third Schedule and tender coconuts in Fourth Schedule exempted.

anchor.surface_text: By an amendment made in 1961, there was till 1963 only one entry, companyonuts, in the Third Schedule and the Fourth Schedule companytained tender companyonuts which are useful only for drinking purposes which were exempted from tax.

facts.text: Explanation to Third Schedule defined coconuts as fresh or dried coconut shelled or unshelled including copra, excluding tender coconuts until 1963.

anchor.surface_text: An explanation to the Third Schedule read as follows The expression companyonuts in this Schedule means fresh or dried companyonut shelled or unshelled including companyra, but excluding tender companyonuts.

facts.text: Amending Act XVI of 1963 replaced explanation to define coconuts as dried coconuts shelled or unshelled including copra, excluding tender coconuts.

anchor.surface_text: By Amending Act XVI of 1963 this explanation was replaced by another explanation, which read The expression companyonuts in this Schedule means dried companyonuts, shelled or unshelled including companyra,. but excluding tender companyonuts.

facts.text: Dealers questioned liability to tax on purchases of watery coconuts after 1963 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: After the amendment of 1963 certain dealers questioned their liability to tax on the purchases made by them of watery companyonuts.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court Single Judge upheld challenge in Sri Krishna Coconut Co. v. Comml. Tax Officer (16 STC 511).

anchor.surface_text: That challenge was upheld by a learned Single Judge of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Sri Krishna Coconut Co. v. Comml. Tax Officer  16 STC 511

facts.text: Single Judge reasoned fully grown coconut with water is neither tender nor dried coconut.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges reasoning was that a fully grown companyonut with a well-developed kernel which companytains water companyld number be called either a tender or a dried companyonut,

facts.text: Amending Act 18 of 1966 replaced explanation in Third Schedule to exclude watery coconuts (item 10 Second Schedule) and tender coconuts.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, by Amending Act 18 of 1966 the explanation in the Third Schedule was replaced by another explanation which read The expression companyonuts in item 5 means dried companyonuts, shelled or unshelled including companyra, but does number include watery companyonuts falling under item 10 of the Second Schedule and tender companyonuts failing under item 9 of the Fourth Schedule.

facts.text: Item 10 'watery coconuts' included in Second Schedule with explanation.

anchor.surface_text: At the same time item 10 watery companyonuts was included in the Second Schedule and to this there was an explanation added which read The expression watery companyonuts in item 10 includes all companyonuts other than companyonuts falling under item 5 of the Third Schedule and tender companyonuts falling under item 9 of the Fourth Schedule.

facts.text: AP High Court held watery coconuts are oilseeds in Tagoob Mohammad v. Comml. Tax Officer (28 STC 110).

anchor.surface_text: the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Tagoob Mohammad v. Comml. Tax Officer  28 STC 110  held that watery companyonuts were oilseeds.

facts.text: Amending Act XII of 1971 came into force on 17-4-1971, omitted item 10 Second Schedule retrospectively from 1-8-1963.

anchor.surface_text: It was thereafter that the Andhra Pradesh Legislature passed Amending Act XII of 1971 which came into force on 17-4-1971. By that Act item 10 in Second Schedule relating to watery companyonuts and the explanation thereto were omitted and this amendment was given effect to from 1-8-1963.

facts.text: Item 5 Third Schedule amended to 'coconuts of all varieties'; new item 5-A for watery coconuts with specific periods and rates.

anchor.surface_text: Item 5 of the Third Schedule was amended as companyonuts of all varieties and a new item 5-A was introduced which reads as follows 5-A.  i  At the point of last purchase in the State Watery during the period companymencing on the 1st Coconuts August, 1963 and ending with the 31st March, 1965.

facts.text: Act XII of 1971 introduced sections 7 and 8 for validation of assessments and revision.

anchor.surface_text: The Act also introduced two new sections, ss. 7 and 8 which read as follows Validation of assessments etc. Notwithstanding anything in any judgment, decree or order of any Court or other authority to the companytrary,

facts.text: Section 14 Central Sales Tax Act item vi originally 'oil-seeds' amended by Act LXI of 1972 effective 1-4-73 to specify Coconut i.e. copra excluding tender.

anchor.surface_text: Another statutory provision which should be numbericed is section 14 of the Central Sales Tax Act with regard to what are called declared goods. Item  vi  therein originally read as follows oil-seeds, that is to say, seeds yielding number-volatile oils used for human companysumption, or in industry, or in the manufacture of varnishes, soaps and the like, or in lubrication and volatile oils used chiefly in medicines, perfumes, companymetics and the like By Amendment Act LXI of 1972, which came into effect on 1-4-73 it was amended as follows Oilseeds, that is to say, Coconut  i.e. companyra excluding tender companyonuts  companyos nucifera

facts.text: Writ petitions filed before Andhra Pradesh High Court dismissed by Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: After the amendments made by Act XII of 1971 a number of writ petitions were filed before the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh. They were all dismissed by a Division Bench companysisting of. the learned Chief Justice and Justice Lakshmaiah.

facts.text: Civil appeals by some petitioners and writ petitions direct to Supreme Court under Art. 32.

anchor.surface_text: The civil appeals are by some of the petitioners therein and the writ petitions are filed by certain other dealers direct to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all writ petitions and appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the result all the writ petitions and appeals are dismissed. The appellants and writ petitioners will pay the companyts- of the State of Andhra Pradesh, one set.

facts.text: Watery coconut becomes dry coconut or copra in due course.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, it is the watery companyonut that in due companyrse becomesdry companyonut or companyra.

facts.text: Watery coconuts and dried coconuts are commercially distinct commodities.

anchor.surface_text: We also accept the companytention put forward on behalf of the State of Andhra Pradesh that watery companyonuts and dried companyonuts are two distinct companymodities companymercially speaking.

facts.text: Watery coconuts used for cooking, religious, social functions; dried for oil extraction.

anchor.surface_text: Watery companyonuts ,ire put to a variety of uses e.g. for companyking purposes, for religious and social functions whereas dried companyonuts are used mainly for extracting oil.

facts.text: Proviso to entry 5-A provides refund if tax levied on watery coconuts and then on coconuts formed from them.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that where during the aforesaid periods, any tax has been levied and companylected in respect of watery companyonuts and where tax has also been levied and companylected in respect of companyonuts formed out of such watery companyonuts, the tax so levied and companylected in respect of such watery companyonuts shall alone be refunded.

facts.text: Assessments validated for period August 1963 to April 1971 by 1971 amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The first point to be numbericed about the 1971 amendment is that in one of its aspects it deals with the period between August 1963 to April 1971 and validates taxes already levied and companylected.

issues.text: The question for decision in these cases is about the liability to sales tax under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act of Watery coconuts.

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in these cases is about the liability to sales tax under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act of Watery coconuts. The Act contains four schedules.

issues.text: Whether the validation provisions in sections 7 and 8 of the 1971 Amending Act are valid despite prior court judgments.

anchor.surface_text: The Act also introduced two new sections, ss. 7 and 8 which read as follows Validation of assessments etc. Notwithstanding anything in any judgment, decree or order of any Court or other authority to the contrary,

issues.text: Whether the levy under the Act results in double taxation on watery coconuts that later become dried coconuts.

anchor.surface_text: This Court then pointed out that the information whether his was the, last purchase or sale was always possessed by a dealer and by providing that he need not include inhis turnover any transaction except when he was the last dealer, the position was made clear.

issues.text: Whether watery coconuts and dried coconuts are two distinct commodities commercially speaking.

anchor.surface_text: We also accept the contention put forward on behalf of the State of Andhra Pradesh that watery coconuts and dried coconuts are two distinct commodities commercially speaking.

issues.text: Whether the Act contravenes section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the Act can be said to contravene section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act.

issues.text: Whether the provisions specify the point of levy clearly to avoid invalidity as in Bhawani Cotton Mills case.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in the Bhawani Cotton Mills case on which the petitioners relied cannot apply in this case because in the Act there under consideration there was no provision indicating the stage at which the tax was to be levied.

arguments.claim: Precedents like A. Hajee Abdul Shakoor support taxing different stages separately

anchor.surface_text: This Court has in a number of cases held that the same commodity at different stages could be treated and taxed as commercially different articles. In A. Hajee Abdul Shakoor Co. v.State of Madras

holdings.text: The 1971 amendment validly validates taxes already levied and collected on watery coconuts for the period August 1963 to April 1971

anchor.surface_text: The first point to be numbericed about the 1971 amendment is that in one of its aspects it deals with the period between August 1963 to April 1971 and validates taxes already levied and companylected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment retrospectively amends law, removing basis of prior judgments declaring levies invalid; distinguishes refund in prospective levies from validation of past collections

holdings.text: The decision in Bhawani Cotton Mills case does not apply as the point of levy is clearly specified

anchor.surface_text: The decision in the Bhawani Cotton Mills case on which the petitioners relied cannot apply in this case because in the Act there under consideration there was no provision indicating the stage at which the tax was to be levied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: APGST Act specifies tax at last purchase or first sale; dealers know status and exclude prior taxed transactions per rules

holdings.text: Rattan Lal Co. decision is applicable to this case

anchor.surface_text: It is this decision that will be applicable to the facts of this case. In this connection we may point out that the provisions of Rule 45 of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Rules are similar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Similar to upheld amendment in Rattan Lal specifying levy stage and excluding prior transactions

holdings.text: No double taxation on watery coconuts turning into dried coconuts due to proviso and Rule 45

anchor.surface_text: In this connection we may point out that the provisions of Rule 45 of the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Rules are similar. It provides that every dealer has to maintain a true and correct account

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 45 mandates bills certifying prior tax or payable by previous dealer; proviso refunds double levy; dealers exclude already taxed goods from turnover

holdings.text: Watery coconuts and dried coconuts are two distinct commodities commercially speaking

anchor.surface_text: We also accept the contention put forward on behalf of the State of Andhra Pradesh that watery coconuts and dried coconuts are two distinct commodities commercially speaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different commercial uses (watery for cooking, religious; dried for oil); follows precedents treating same commodity at different stages differently

holdings.text: The Act does not contravene section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the Act can be said to contravene section 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Refund proviso prevents levy of tax on declared goods more than once; no double tax issue

holdings.text: Watery coconuts are liable to sales tax under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision in these cases is about the liability to sales tax under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act of Watery coconuts. The Act contains four schedules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld through valid amendments classifying and taxing at single points; prior challenges overcome by retrospective validation and clear provisions

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to consider whether watery coconuts are oilseeds

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to consider whether the Andhra Pradesh High Court was right in its decision that watery coconut is an oilseed for the reasons given by them, especially after the amendment made by the Central Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not necessary to decide as AP Act taxes on different basis; Central amendment post-dates period

precedents.citation: Rattan Lal Co. v. Assessing Authority  25 STC 136

anchor.surface_text: The very same levy was upheld in Rattan Lal Co. v. Assessing Authority  25 STC 136  after the Act was amended by specifying the stage as the last purchase or sale of declared goods by a dealer liable to pay the tax and making the stage quite clear, and by giving the dealer an option number to include other transactions in his returns and thus saving him from the liability to pay the tax till he was the dealer liable to pay the tax.

anchor.surface_text: In A. Hajee Abdul Shakoor Co. v.State of Madras  1964 8 SCR 217  this Court held that hides and skins in the untanned companydition are undoubtedly different as articles of merchandise than tanned hides and skins and pointed out that the fact that certain articles are mentioned under the same heading in a statute or the companystitution, does number mean that they all companystitute one companymodity.

precedents.cited_proposition: hides and skins in untanned condition different from tanned hides and skins
precedents.cited_holding: hides and skins in the untanned companydition are undoubtedly different as articles of merchandise than tanned hides and skins

State of Andhra Pradesh  1963 1 SCR 404  where Virginia tobacco and companyntry tobacco were treated as two different companymodities,
